ground_truth: Uncle Billy picks it up. Potter is seated behind his desk, with his goon alongside him. Standing in front of the desk is a distinguished-looking man, obviously the president of the bank, mopping his brow with his handkerchief. George bangs the receiver down and turns to meet Uncle Billy's anxious look. He realizes George has hung up and clicks the phone furiously. An ominous sound of angry voices comes from the other room. George and Uncle Billy exit from George's office, and more people have crowded around the counter. Their muttering stops, and they stand silent and grim, with panic on their faces. As George speaks, sirens are heard passing in the street below. The crowd turns to the windows, then back to George. Mary and Ernie have come into the room during this scene, with Mary watching silently. A man named Randall comes in and makes his way up to Tom. Randall starts out, and a few other people start for the door. The camera pans with George as he vaults over the counter quickly, speaking to the people. The people are still trying to get out, but some of them have stood still, listening to him. George has begun to make an impression on them. During this scene, Mary has come up behind the counter. Suddenly, as the people once more start moving toward the door, she holds up a roll of bills and calls out. George jumps over the counter and takes the money from Mary. Mary turns and slips out through the crowd, followed by Ernie. George hands the two hundred and forty-two dollars to Tom and speaks to Ed, the next in line. Uncle Billy takes out his wallet and takes out all the cash he's got. George, Uncle Billy, and Cousin Tilly are behind the counter, watching the minute hand of a clock on the wall as George counts off the seconds. Cousin Eustace is ready to close the door. Cousin Eustace slams and locks the door and scurries around the counter to join the others. Uncle Billy is taking a drink out of his bottle. The four of them parade through the office; George puts the two dollars in the safe. George rushes into his office to look out the window. George hurries into the scene. An old-fashioned, run-down house, unpainted and warped by the weather, once had class but has not been lived in for years. This is the house that George and Mary will live in from now on. The rain is pouring down, and a faint glow of light shines out from the bottom windows. He stops to make sure it is the right number before going up the steps. Bert and a man are working in the rain, sorting through travel posters.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Uncle Billy lifts it. Potter is perched behind his desk, with his thug beside him. Stationed in front of the desk is a refined-appearing gentleman, clearly the head of the bank, wiping his forehead with his kerchief. George slams the handset down and rotates to face Uncle Billy's worried gaze. He perceives George has disconnected and taps the telephone angrily. A foreboding noise of irate voices emanates from the other chamber. George and Uncle Billy depart from George's office, and additional individuals have clustered around the counter. Their murmuring ceases, and they stand mute and stern, with dread on their features. As George speaks, alarms are audible passing in the avenue below. The throng turns to the panes, then back to George. Mary and Ernie have entered the room during this scene, with Mary observing silently. A gentleman named Randall enters and maneuvers up to Tom. Randall departs, and a few other individuals head for the entry. The camera follows George as he bounds over the counter swiftly, addressing the individuals. The individuals are still striving to exit, but some of them have paused, listening to him. George has commenced to create an effect on them. During this sequence, Mary has come up behind the counter. Abruptly, as the individuals once more start advancing toward the door, she raises a bundle of currency and shouts out. George leaps over the counter and receives the money from Mary. Mary turns and slips out through the throng, trailed by Ernie. George hands the two hundred and forty-two dollars to Tom and addresses Ed, the subsequent in line. Uncle Billy pulls out his billfold and extracts all the currency he's got. George, Uncle Billy, and Cousin Tilly are behind the counter, observing the second hand of a clock on the wall as George tallies off the moments. Cousin Eustace is prepared to fasten the door. Cousin Eustace slams and latches the door and dashes around the counter to join the others. Uncle Billy is taking a swig out of his flask. The quartet of them march through the office; George puts the two dollars in the vault. George dashes into his office to peer out the window. George rushes into the scene. An antiquated, dilapidated residence, unpainted and warped by the weather, once had elegance but has not been occupied for years. This is the dwelling that George and Mary will reside in from now on. The rain is pouring down, and a faint glow of light radiates out from the bottom windows. He pauses to ensure it is the correct number before ascending the steps. Bert and a man are laboring in the rain, sorting through travel posters.

To Tom, George hands the two hundred and forty-two dollars and speaks to Ed, the next in line. From his wallet, Uncle Billy takes out all the cash he's got. test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Uncle Billy picks up the phone. Potter sits at his desk, with his associate beside him. In front stands a distinguished bank president, mopping his brow. George hangs up angrily and turns to Uncle Billy's worried face. An ominous murmur arises from another room as George and Uncle Billy leave his office. A crowd surrounds the counter, silent and panicked. As George speaks, sirens pass by, drawing the crowd's attention to the windows. Mary and Ernie enter the room; Mary watches silently. Randall arrives, approaches Tom, and heads for the door. The camera follows George vaulting the counter, addressing the crowd. Some remain to listen as George begins to sway them. Mary stands behind the counter and raises a roll of bills, prompting George to jump over and take it. Mary slips through the crowd, followed by Ernie. George hands $242 to Tom and speaks to Ed. Uncle Billy empties his wallet, and they, with Cousin Tilly, watch the clock as George counts seconds. Cousin Eustace locks the door and joins them. Uncle Billy takes a drink. They parade through the office; George secures two dollars in the safe and rushes to the window. George hurries to a dilapidated, uninhabited house, weather-worn yet once classy, now his and Mary's. In pouring rain, he ensures it's the right number before ascending the steps. Bert and another man work in the rain, sorting travel posters.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Uncle Billy picks it up. Potter sits behind his desk with his goon. A distinguished man, likely the bank president, wipes his brow with a handkerchief. George hangs up, meeting Uncle Billy's anxious look. An ominous sound of angry voices is heard. George and Uncle Billy leave the office to find the crowd silent and panicked. Sirens pass below as George speaks. Mary and Ernie enter, with Mary silent. Randall arrives and approaches Tom. Randall and others head for the door. George vaults over the counter to speak, some people stopping to listen. Mary appears behind the counter, holding cash, stopping the crowd. George takes the money from Mary, who leaves with Ernie. He gives $242 to Tom and speaks to Ed. Uncle Billy takes out his cash. George, Uncle Billy, and Cousin Tilly watch the clock. Cousin Eustace locks the door, joining them. Uncle Billy drinks from a bottle. They parade through the office; George puts two dollars in the safe, then looks out the window. George hurries outside to an old, run-down house where he and Mary will live. In the rain, Bert and a man sort travel posters.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Uncle Billy, with a swift and deliberate motion, picks it up. Inside the room, Potter sits comfortably behind his imposing desk, with his loyal goon standing vigilantly at his side. Positioned in front of the desk is an important-looking gentleman, clearly distinguished as the president of the bank, who is diligently mopping the perspiration from his brow with a handkerchief. George, with a decisive gesture, bangs the telephone receiver down onto its cradle and turns to face Uncle Billy, who wears an anxious expression. Uncle Billy, realizing that George has severed the connection, clicks the phone angrily in frustration. From the adjacent room, an ominous surge of angry voices fills the air. George and Uncle Billy make their way out of George's office, only to be met by a larger crowd that has gathered around the counter. The crowd's murmuring ceases abruptly, leaving them to stand there, silent and grim-faced, their expressions marked by panic. As George begins to address them, the sound of sirens wailing in the street below can be heard, prompting the crowd to turn to the windows momentarily before refocusing their attention on George. Meanwhile, Mary and Ernie quietly enter the room during this unfolding drama, with Mary intently observing. A man named Randall makes his entrance and heads toward Tom. Randall starts to leave, and a few others follow suit, heading toward the door. The camera smoothly pans with George as he vaults over the counter with agility, speaking directly to the people. Although some people are still attempting to make their way out, a portion of the crowd pauses to listen intently to George, who is beginning to make a noticeable impression on them. Throughout this scene, Mary has subtly made her way behind the counter. Suddenly, just as the crowd begins to move toward the door once more, she holds up a roll of bills and calls out. George quickly leaps back over the counter and takes the money from Mary. Mary then turns and skillfully maneuvers through the crowd, with Ernie following closely behind her. George hands the two hundred and forty-two dollars over to Tom and then directs his attention to Ed, who is next in line. In a moment of shared urgency, Uncle Billy retrieves his wallet and pulls out all the cash he has on hand. Together, George, Uncle Billy, and Cousin Tilly stand behind the counter, their eyes fixed on the clock's minute hand as George meticulously counts down the seconds. Ready to act, Cousin Eustace stands by the door and, with a decisive motion, slams it shut and locks it, before hurrying around the counter to join the others. Uncle Billy takes a swig from his bottle, and the four of them parade through the office. With a sense of resolve, George places the two dollars securely in the safe. He then rushes into his office to glance out the window. George hurries into the unfolding scene. The camera reveals an old-fashioned, deteriorated house, its exterior unpainted and warped by years of harsh weather. Once upon a time, it had class, but now it stands uninhabited and neglected. This is the very house where George and Mary will begin their new life together. The rain pours down relentlessly, while a faint glow emanates from the bottom windows, casting a soft light. George stops momentarily to ensure he has the correct address before ascending the steps. In the rain, Bert and another individual work diligently, sorting through a collection of travel posters.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Uncle Billy, with a swift and deliberate motion that seems almost second nature to him, reaches down and picks it up with ease. Inside the room, Potter sits comfortably, ensconced behind his imposing, authoritative desk, with his loyal goon standing vigilantly at his side, ever watchful. Positioned in front of the desk sits an important-looking gentleman, who is clearly distinguished as the president of the bank. This gentleman is diligently mopping the perspiration from his brow with a handkerchief, a sign of his nervousness. George, with a decisive gesture that leaves no room for doubt, bangs the telephone receiver down onto its cradle with a sense of finality, turning to face Uncle Billy, who wears an anxious expression etched across his face. Uncle Billy, immediately realizing that George has severed the connection, clicks the phone repeatedly and angrily in frustration. From the adjacent room, an ominous surge of angry voices fills the air, growing louder. George and Uncle Billy make their way out of George's office, only to find themselves met by a larger crowd that has gathered around the counter. The crowd's murmuring ceases abruptly, leaving them to stand there, silent and grim-faced, their expressions marked by a palpable sense of panic. As George begins to address them, the sound of sirens wailing in the street below can be heard echoing through the room, prompting the crowd to turn to the windows momentarily before refocusing their attention on George's words. Meanwhile, Mary and Ernie quietly enter the room during this unfolding drama, with Mary intently observing all that transpires. A man named Randall makes his entrance, heading directly toward Tom. Randall starts to leave, and a few others follow suit, heading purposefully toward the door. The camera smoothly pans with George as he vaults over the counter with agility and urgency, speaking directly to the people in an attempt to calm them. Although some people are still attempting to make their way out, a portion of the crowd pauses to listen, their attention now intently focused on George, who is beginning to make a noticeable impression on them. Throughout this scene, Mary has subtly made her way behind the counter with purpose. Suddenly, just as the crowd begins to move toward the door once more, she holds up a roll of bills and calls out with authority. George quickly leaps back over the counter and takes the money from Mary, thankful for her assistance. Mary then turns and skillfully maneuvers through the crowd, with Ernie following closely behind her, ensuring they do not lose sight of each other. George hands the two hundred and forty-two dollars over to Tom and then directs his attention to Ed, who is next in line. In a moment of shared urgency and determination, Uncle Billy retrieves his wallet and hastily pulls out all the cash he has on hand. Together, George, Uncle Billy, and Cousin Tilly stand behind the counter, their eyes fixed on the clock's minute hand, watching it as George meticulously counts down the seconds with anticipation. Ready to act and with a sense of urgency, Cousin Eustace stands by the door and, with a decisive motion, slams it shut and locks it securely, before hurrying around the counter to join the others in their efforts. Uncle Billy takes a quick swig from his bottle, gathering his resolve, and the four of them parade through the office, united in purpose. With a sense of resolve and determination, George places the two dollars securely in the safe, ensuring its safety. He then rushes into his office with urgency to glance out the window, assessing the situation outside. George hurries into the unfolding scene, the camera capturing every moment. The camera reveals an old-fashioned, deteriorated house, its exterior unpainted and warped by years of harsh weather, a testament to its age. Once upon a time, it had class and elegance, but now it stands uninhabited and neglected, a shadow of its former glory. This is the very house where George and Mary will begin their new life together, a place full of potential despite its current state. The rain pours down relentlessly, soaking the ground, while a faint glow emanates from the bottom windows, casting a soft, welcoming light that holds promise. George stops momentarily to ensure he has the correct address, double-checking before ascending the steps purposefully. In the pouring rain, Bert and another individual work diligently, sorting through a collection of travel posters, their dedication unwavering despite the weather.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Uncle Billy's hand reaches down to grasp the object, and as he lifts it, his actions unfold in the presence of Potter, who remains seated behind his desk, exuding an air of authority. Beside him stands his intimidating associate, maintaining an unwavering presence. Positioned before Potter's imposing desk is a man of refined appearance, unmistakably the president of the bank, who continuously dabs at his brow with a handkerchief, attempting to mitigate his evident stress. At this moment, George, consumed by frustration, slams the telephone receiver down with force and swivels to face Uncle Billy, whose expression is one of acute anxiety. Recognizing that George has disconnected the call, Uncle Billy, agitated, repeatedly clicks the phone in a futile effort. From the adjoining room emanates a foreboding cacophony of angry voices, suggesting escalating tension. In response, George and Uncle Billy make a decisive move, departing from George's office to find a growing throng of people clustered around the counter, their murmurs ceasing abruptly as they stand in tense silence, panic etched on their faces. As George begins to address the assembly, the distant sound of sirens wailing in the street below momentarily diverts the crowd's attention to the windows before they refocus on George. During this charged scene, Mary and Ernie have quietly entered the room, with Mary observing events in silence. Amid the gathering, a man named Randall emerges, threading his way through the crowd to reach Tom, then turns to leave, accompanied by a few others heading for the door. Tracking George's energetic movements, the camera captures him as he swiftly vaults over the counter, engaging with the people in an attempt to calm them. While some individuals continue to push toward the exit, others pause, drawn in by George's words and beginning to absorb his message. In the midst of this, Mary approaches the counter, and as the crowd once again moves toward the door, she suddenly raises a roll of bills, her call cutting through the noise. Reacting promptly, George leaps back over the counter to retrieve the money from Mary, who then discreetly maneuvers through the throng, with Ernie close behind her. George promptly hands the two hundred and forty-two dollars to Tom, simultaneously addressing Ed, the next person in line. Meanwhile, Uncle Billy reaches for his wallet, extracting every last bill he possesses. Behind the counter, George, Uncle Billy, and Cousin Tilly watch intently as the wall clock's minute hand ticks forward, with George counting each second aloud. Prepared to secure the premises, Cousin Eustace moves to close the door, shutting and locking it with determination before darting around the counter to join the others. Amidst these actions, Uncle Billy pauses to take a swig from his bottle. The quartet then makes their way through the office in procession; George carefully places the two dollars into the safe for safekeeping. Urgently, George dashes into his office, positioning himself at the window to survey the situation outside. He then quickly immerses himself in the unfolding scene. The narrative shifts to an old-fashioned, deteriorated house, its exterior weather-beaten and lacking paint, a shadow of its former elegance and long abandoned. This is the dwelling where George and Mary are destined to reside from this point forward, where the relentless rain pours down, and a faint glow emanates from the lower windows. George pauses to verify the house number, ensuring its accuracy, before proceeding up the steps. Meanwhile, out in the rain, Bert, accompanied by another man, labors on, sorting meticulously through piles of travel posters.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Uncle Billy picks up the device as Potter sits behind his desk with his assistant, while a distinguished bank president wipes his brow in front of them. After George hangs up the phone and meets Uncle Billy’s anxious gaze, angry voices echo from the other room. George and Uncle Billy exit to find a growing crowd around the counter, their panic evident. As George begins speaking, sirens pass outside, drawing the crowd's attention momentarily before they refocus on him. Mary and Ernie arrive, with Mary observing quietly. Randall enters, approaches Tom, and then leaves with others. As George speaks over the counter, capturing the crowd's attention, Mary emerges with a roll of bills, prompting George to jump over and take the money. Mary and Ernie make their way out. George distributes $242 to Tom and addresses Ed. Uncle Billy empties his wallet, and alongside Cousin Tilly, they monitor the clock as George counts seconds. Cousin Eustace locks the door and joins them, as Uncle Billy takes a drink. They all parade through the office, with George securing the remaining $2 in the safe. He then rushes to his office window. George arrives at a rundown, old-fashioned house that he and Mary will call home, ensuring it's the right address before ascending the steps. Meanwhile, Bert and another man sort through travel posters in the rain.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Uncle Billy picks it up. Potter, a notorious businessman known for his ruthless dealings in the community, is seated behind his desk, with his goon, a tall and imposing figure often seen intimidating locals, alongside him. Standing in front of the desk is a distinguished-looking man, obviously the president of the bank, mopping his brow with his handkerchief, a common gesture revealing the stress of the ongoing financial crisis affecting the town. George bangs the receiver down and turns to meet Uncle Billy's anxious look. He realizes George has hung up and clicks the phone furiously, a sign of the mounting tension as the bank faces a potential run. An ominous sound of angry voices comes from the other room, echoing the town's growing unrest. George and Uncle Billy exit from George's office, and more people, a mix of worried depositors and concerned citizens, have crowded around the counter. Their muttering stops, and they stand silent and grim, with panic on their faces as they fear losing their savings. As George speaks, sirens, likely from emergency vehicles responding to the chaos, are heard passing in the street below. The crowd turns to the windows, then back to George. Mary, George's supportive wife, and Ernie, a loyal friend who runs the local taxi service, have come into the room during this scene, with Mary watching silently. A man named Randall, a respected local businessman, comes in and makes his way up to Tom. Randall starts out, and a few other people, sensing a spark of hope from George’s words, start for the door. The camera pans with George as he vaults over the counter quickly, speaking to the people in an attempt to calm them. The people are still trying to get out, but some of them have stood still, listening to him, captivated by his charisma and sincerity. George has begun to make an impression on them, easing their panic. During this scene, Mary has come up behind the counter. Suddenly, as the people once more start moving toward the door, she holds up a roll of bills and calls out, offering their personal savings to keep the bank afloat. George jumps over the counter and takes the money from Mary, the sum representing their determination to support their community. Mary turns and slips out through the crowd, followed by Ernie, who’s there to provide transportation and aid as needed. George hands the two hundred and forty-two dollars, a significant amount in those days, to Tom and speaks to Ed, the next in line, reassuring them with his resolve. Uncle Billy takes out his wallet and takes out all the cash he's got, contributing to the communal effort to stabilize the situation. George, Uncle Billy, and Cousin Tilly, a devoted family member known for her sharp wit, are behind the counter, watching the minute hand of a clock on the wall as George counts off the seconds, each tick a reminder of the delicate balance they maintain. Cousin Eustace, known for his meticulous nature, is ready to close the door. Cousin Eustace slams and locks the door and scurries around the counter to join the others, ensuring that order is maintained. Uncle Billy is taking a drink out of his bottle, a habitual action indicating his struggle with stress. The four of them parade through the office; George puts the two dollars, a symbolic gesture of hope and resilience, in the safe. George rushes into his office to look out the window, checking on the stormy weather as it mirrors their turbulent situation. George hurries into the scene. An old-fashioned, run-down house, unpainted and warped by the weather, once had class but has not been lived in for years, standing as a testament to their dreams of revival and new beginnings. This is the house that George and Mary will live in from now on, marking the start of their journey together. The rain is pouring down, and a faint glow of light shines out from the bottom windows, symbolizing hope amidst adversity. He stops to make sure it is the right number before going up the steps, pausing in a moment of reflection. Bert, the dependable local police officer, and a man are working in the rain, sorting through travel posters that evoke dreams of distant places and new possibilities, even as they stand firm in their commitment to their home.

Standing in front of the desk is a distinguishedlooking man obviously the president of the bank mopping his brow with his handkerchief. George bangs the receiver down and turns to meet Uncle Billy's anxious look. He realizes George has hung up and clicks the phone furiously. An ominous sound of angry voices comes from the other room. George and Uncle Billy exit from George's office and more people have crowded around the counter. Their muttering stops and they stand silent and grim with panic on their faces. Mary and Ernie have come into the room during this scene with Mary watching silently. A man named Randall comes in and makes his way up to Tom. Randall starts out and a few other people start for the door. The camera pans with George as he vaults over the counter quickly speaking to the people. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Uncle Billy retrieves a package as Potter and his goon watch a distinguished bank president nervously wipe his brow. An anxious George ends a phone call, creating tension. Angry voices lead George and Uncle Billy outside, where a worried crowd waits with panic in their eyes. Mary and Ernie quietly enter, and Randall tries to leave, but George makes a compelling speech, calming some. Mary presents a roll of bills, which George uses to help the crowd, assisted by Uncle Billy's remaining cash. Behind the counter, he, Uncle Billy, and Cousin Tilly anxiously watch the clock. Cousin Eustace locks the door as George secures the money. He spots a run-down house, dimly lit, which he and Mary will make their home despite the rain. Bert and another man organize travel posters nearby.

test_cases.name: Jumble Segments Order
test_cases.description: The crowd turns to the windows then back to George Randall starts out and a few other people start for the door An ominous sound of angry voices comes from the other room George puts the two dollars in the safe This is the house that George and Mary will live in from now on Mary turns and slips out through the crowd followed by Ernie An oldfashioned rundown house unpainted and warped by the weather Uncle Billy is taking a drink out of his bottle Uncle Billy and Cousin Tilly are behind the counter watching the minute hand of a clock on the wall as George counts off the seconds The four of them parade through the office once had class but has not been lived in for years Mary and Ernie have come into the room during this scene with Mary watching silently A man named Randall comes in and makes his way up to Tom George rushes into his office to look out the window As George speaks sirens are heard passing in the street below George hands the two hundred and fortytwo dollars to Tom and speaks to Ed the next in line During this scene Mary has come up behind the counter Bert and a man are working in the rain sorting through travel posters George and Uncle Billy exit from George's office and more people have crowded around the counter Cousin Eustace slams and locks the door and scurries around the counter to join the others Uncle Billy picks it up He stops to make sure it is the right number before going up the steps The camera pans with George as he vaults over the counter quickly speaking to the people George jumps over the counter and takes the money from Mary Standing in front of the desk is a distinguishedlooking man obviously the president of the bank mopping his brow with his handkerchief The rain is pouring down and a faint glow of light shines out from the bottom windows George hurries into the scene Uncle Billy takes out his wallet and takes out all the cash he is got George George bangs the receiver down and turns to meet Uncle Billy's anxious look Cousin Eustace is ready to close the door He realizes George has hung up and clicks the phone furiously The people are still trying to get out but some of them have stood still listening to him George has begun to make an impression on them Suddenly as the people once more start moving toward the door she holds up a roll of bills and calls out Potter is seated behind his desk with his goon alongside him Their muttering stops and they stand silent and grim with panic on their faces
